comment.author: 21417004@N08
comment._content: Amazing, considering what POW's on the other side were going through.

comment.author: 7616211@N08
comment._content:
Indeed,but the British P.O.W's were not much better off than the German public,due to the blockade by the Royal NAvy.
My great uncle was a WW1 P.O.W,captured in 1917 and sent to work in a salt mine in Prussia,not released and returned home til MArch 1919.
His brother was killed on the first day of the Somme,1st July 1916 after just over a year in France and Belgium,he was gassed within a week of l;anding in France and being posted at Hill 60 in May 1915,two weeks after his 19th birthday.

All boys,just boys
